div.p: ROMES ECCHO OR A DIALOGVE BETVVIXT A PAPIST AND A PROTESTANT: VVITH AN ADMONITION TO OVR LORDLY BISHOPS.
And a briefe Relation of the suffering of that worthy and Religious Devine Master BATES, and the Inhumane usage of his dead bones afterward.
Who died in the Gatehouse, under the Bishops Tyrannie.

q.p: A Righteous man regardeth the life of his Beast, but the tender mercies of the wicked are cruell.

div.p: Printed in the Wonderfull Yeare of God, 1641.

div.head: A Caveate for Lordly Bishops.
div.l: COme downe ye Bishops feare a fall
your kingdome 'ginnes to shake:
the hand is writing on the wall
which makes your knees to quake.
Your building like a tottering wall
the ground workes laid in sand
Come downe it will take Babels fall
sure long it cannot stand:
Your language is confounded sure
you wote not what to say;
And yet to build up Babels tower,
you still bring clods of clay.
But all this while you patch, and peece
with paultrie stuffe indeed;
So that in th'end the marke you misse
when you hope best to speed.
It is not Ierobams calves
can save you I am sure;
Nor yet your cruell Canon Lawes
can make your Kingdome dure.
You have deprived many a man
for breaking mans decrees;
But for the Lawes of God not one
that doth his living leese.
How can this stand with equity
resolve me this I pray:
To maintaine guides that cannot see,
and thrust the good away.
For let him be the vilest wretch
that lives under the sunne;
If he will weare a Surplesse,
and crosse the Child with thumbe.
Hee's countenanced still by you
much better then the best
If this prove not to be too true,
then let me have no rest
You sell most foule adulteries
for silver and for gold.
The poore must crouch upon his knees
by you to be absolud.
And sometimes you blesse Iack for Iill
if silver doe appeare;
If not then sometimes say you will;
poore knave what dost thou here.
You thinke to have your heaven here,
and after heaven too;
But I can tell you in your eare,
that will be much adoe.
For you be growne so monstrous great,
even now adayes of late;
That 'twill goe hard for you to get
in at the narrow gate.
Therefore me thinks it were the best
if you could so agree;
To let your hearts have now no rest
till you unladen bee.
Of all your pome, and glorious state
which causeth God to frowne;
Which sinne of yours he doth so hate
that sure you must come downe.
For sure the Word of God is true,
and doe it not forget;
He will pluck up I say to you
those plants h • never set.

div.head: ROMES ECCHO IN A Dialogue betweene a Protestant and a Papist.

sp.speaker: Protestant.
sp.l: VVHat newes Sir shaveling heare you none?
you should know some I thinke,
For many times if any stirre

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Yea some there is one Hildershum
for that he thought not meete,

sp.speaker: Protestant.
sp.l: Me thinks I should well know the man,
Is it not one, doth what he can,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Its he, but wote you, one that then
In learned sort, and open Court,
Youd faine know how, I tell it now
In sober wise, he doth advise,
and tells him this plaine lye,
That Banbury men were stiffe at first,
But now they would doe best & worst,
And you (saith he) will peevish be,
And there perhaps ere long like Bates

sp.speaker: Protestant.
sp.l: What said he thus? then had he quite
But that he knew, it was not true,
For thus to speake of worthy Bates,
What though we be not so precise,
We are perswaded he liv'd well,
Will Turner think you turne his coate,
and say he cares not what?
Wil Sharpe of Banbury change his noate
and now goe sing a flat?
No Turner stood, and heard this tale,
The Bishop vent so foule untruthes,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Well true or false it matters not,
Why we resolve their Lordships have,
And truely they deserve our Church,
In shew they much oppose, in deed
What though they rate us now and then
And call us powder plotting men,
that so we may be shent.
Though you, and they doe terme us oft,
Yet they, and we doe well agree,
they must needs make faire weather,
They know full wel their cause, & ours,
Of such Precesians what they can,
And leave in Pulpit scarce a man,

sp.speaker: Protestant.
sp.l: Yes sundry men soundlie to taxe,
Your masse, your vowes, your pilgrimage
Your salt, your spitile, and your creame,
Your Church beliefe, your merits, works
Your legens, bulls, base fretting toyes
Your Iewish churching, and such like
All which our learned Cleargie men,

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: In words 'tis true your Clergie men
But who sees not therein they give
We sometimes heare, & well can beare,
Provided though they doe not eate
our meate, they sup our pottage.
In sence can these be practised,
The blusters which your Doctors make,
is but a blast of breath:
Theres in it no such danger 'tis
and cause to bow the knee:
When as they do take, and eate
the bread as well as we.
They must put on our worthy weedes
And do such rites for which what word,
And coyne some from his owne conceit,
What order have we you have not
stands on the selfe same grounds.
You keepe our fasts, and feasting dayes,
Our Canons, and your lawes, from us
Some worthy points whereof there is
All points wherein we well accord
Abbot to Tim. Lowel.On Fishstreet hill one gives the bread
but would not give the cup.
Doctor Layfield.One pleads in pulpit for our faith
And saith none kneelers must be damn'd
they can it no way shift.

M. Hayw •••
A third to prove your kneeling good
Reads in our Masse booke word for word
Our Church as good retaines, & which
in act, and shunne the name,
Like usurers, when as our worke,
Our robes must be your ornaments,
Our churchings are your giving thanks
In stead of our procession, you
Is now become your Christian badge,
and no small signe of grace.
Your Churches, if you pull them downe
If Banbury men will doe their geere,
I trow they have their doome,
Their orders are well stuft I heare
Yea worthy newes I hope ere this
And so concludes that who so doth
A ha Sir Large how like you this,
did he not say the troth:
That said you would soon eate our meat
that thus fell to our broth?
What practise we that you doe not?
have we stewes, you have stage?
Pardon we faults, you let forth fees
The strumpet poore must penance pay
the rich hath no such harme.
Sometimes in deed for verie need
When with bare brest & head bare drest
In briefe what ere may be the fruite
The same is of your punishing,
of sinne by sheet or purse:
Nay further name a sin who can
Let any that will not conforme,
The feathered cap, the Saffron ruffe,
Some galled horse beginnes to snuffe
Nay let him preach for loyaltie,
Yea plead, and pray most fervently
Let him for Princes health, and peace
There's not a Papist in the place
But hath a trick to fetch him up,
and well nigh pull him downe.
Where are the thousand men become,
A Rave bird with his heady booke,
But this our Doctors proctors could
They would have no Non residents,
And yet have but due recompence,
Theyld no Comendams have, theyld no
They shot at Rovers yet how right,
They would have mended many things
which none of us can brooke.
And have therein all formall men,
Yet should it come to patting wealth,
its feard they would stand out.
They would joyne close for Prince, and State
Its thought they would not part with these
Tis this, hearke in your eare a word
that puts us to our pause
That we trie not with dint of sword,

sp.speaker: Protestant.
sp.l: And heare him longer they that list,
See how he hath the bloudy minds,
More meet their cause by Princes lawes,
And are our Prelates Popish then?
I thought they had beene wise,
I tooke them for good Protestants,
Oft have I heard a sore (it is
I meane such as those Impes doe terme;
He tells us plainely whom the Pope,
He brings to mind an adage ould,
which once I saw in verse,
Its not so new, nor old as true,
Why stay I thus? and presently,
And in the eares of Prince, and Peeres,
Why joyne wee not that would be thought
First to the Lord then to the King,
Why seeke we not by all good meanes
And by true Christian force unite,
Is Princes life so little worth
Must wives and children be to sword
Shall sharking Spaniard share our goods
Our lands possesse we purchast have,
Much better true Church rule were sought
that these things might be stay'd,
Who ever heard that such as stand,
In Popish plot had head, or hand
To Church her ancient parish right
It's this you see would daunt our foes
But if we walking as before
The Lord hath sent his Ministers,
Some ended have their daies in bands,
That wives, and children here, & there
No marvell if ere long we heare
Our people perish in their sinnes
Its not unknowne that Diggers first
Where Preachers silent, first were forst,
But let's have these restor'd, let no
Let such as have crept in returne
He preaching were, not prisoner, meete
in Kings bench, or the Fleete.
Let others more be set at large.
Let Leicester men have their discharge,
Downe with the cursed office oath
The things their patrons count toyes
Let learned men not formall but boyes
be set the flocke to feed.
In briefe, lets all submit to Christ
Its this to Country, State, and Prince
But as for those that be his foes,
and wil not have him raigne;
In woefull plight into his sight,
they shall be brought, and slaine.
Reader heres mention made of Bates
Adding thereto the song that thus

div.head: HERE FOLLOVVETH A BRIEFE RELATION OF THE DEATH of that worthie Master Bates, who being a Prisoner in the Gatehouse, dyed the second of October 1613. a faithfull witnesse of of the Truth. With some briefe notes of the cause why others are still imprisoned.
div.l: RIght Reverend Randall Bates at length
when twenty moneths were past
God freed from Gatehouse into which
he causelesly was cast.
He dyed not in contempt of lawes,
or lawfull Magistrate,
But baring witnesse in the cause
against the Romish state.
His Prince he lov'd, those whom he sent
he readily obeyd:
And patiently he underwent
what others one him laid.
More loyall, faithfull to the state,
for King, and Kingdomes good,
Then those who by restraint impair'd
his health, and truth withstood.
More fit for heaven say they, tis true
but woe to them that spill,
The bloud of saints with crueltie,
their measure to fulfill.
Release was sought, but what successe
they did not blush for shame,
To say the King would have it thus,
loe he must beare the blame.
Though Iaylor shut all in, and out
with locke and key full sure,
They feare the corps is thence conve • ' •
they cannot be secure,
The Coffin up they brake, the sheete
they see, but then they doubt,
Some image lies in wrapt in stead
of bodie taken out
The sheet they loose, the corpes they view
yet when his face they see,
They knew him not they say, or doubt
at least it is not he,
Some of their owne must say or swear
and so content the spies,
Thus all his servants wicked are,
that harken unto lies.
All what I could of whats too true
to speake I would be loath:
Of all their men shew but the man
loves God or feares an oath.
With Surplice, Tipp • t and such trash,
with mockes and much disdaine,
They flout him when they could inflict
on him no further paine.
Indeed he hated, so doth God
the Popish prelacie,
Rom • s remnants relique • , rights, & rags Christ
with her conformity,
To grave with bills, and staves, as
was taken brought was he,
A greater then the master is
the servant may not be.
Yea further, that they might not much
their patterne misse to match,
Its said that some their care was such
that night the grave did watch.
He lives with Christ in happinesse,
for all Eternity,
His friends he left in heavinesse,
his foes in miserie.
Those though they waile are yet in way
to heaven where all is well:
But these unlesse they doe repent,
in woe, and way to Hell.
Ye that lament him cease your moane,
your heads no more hang downe,
The race is runne, the field is wonne,
he hath the prise, and crowne.
He fought the fight, and kept the faith,
he spake it oft, now plaine
He proves i • never any serv'd
the living God in vaine.
Mourne for your selves, & those whose rage
shall cease or downfalls nere,
It well be knowne God loves his owne
the death of Saints is deare.
They'l now repent, would that were true
small hope as yet we see,
Since Banbury men be in a new,
against all equitie.
Theres sure some cause yea this is one,
its said they were too bold:
To throw downe images of stones,
a part of Popes freehold
Whilst, that were grosse, they will not take
the selfe accusing oath,
What man of grace so much can make
as one just cause of both?
Yet first they were to prison brought,
and now cast in againe,
Because they did that which they ought
and feare to sweare in vaine.
On others likewise long restraind
their anger still they wreakee
The second precept, third or ninth,
enforcing them to breake,
Enforcing, yea say not, he speaks
he knowes not what, nor how,
Twas said by one, of him that's gone,
that he should breake or bow.
But God will bow, and bend the back,
or breake the teeth, and jawes:
Of such as doe oppresse the poore
under pretence of lawes.
Be patient therefore waite a while
the Lord our God will come,
And fellow servants smitters shal,
receive a dreadfull doome.
Oh have compassion, pitty, pray
that God his grace would give:
They may repent, and so prevent
his heavie hand, and live.
Praise God for Princes life, and peace,
who whilst he Septer swayes,
Keeps from us (what the Papists would
bring on us) bitter dayes,
Save Lord thy Church, this land & state
our King, and Prince prorect:
And by his race confound the Pope,
and comfort thine elect.
Shew us thy face in princes grace
discerning truth from guile,
His subjects truth from popish crew
the precious from the vile.
Pardon our sinnes, and purge our soules.
make glad our hearts againe,
We may by grace, with thee our race
here runne, hereafter raigne.
